titleStmt.title: Brief von Lotte Labowsky an Raymond Klibansky vom 12. Februar 1949

lg.l: UNIVERSITY OF LONDON
THE WARBURG INSITUTE
IMPERIAL INSTITUTE BUILDINGS
SOUTH KENSINGTON
LONDON S. W. 7.
TELEPHONE: KENSINGTON 9077
My dear Raymond,
Thank you very much for your
two handwritten letters the second of which arrived the
day before yesterday. Both were evidently written in
great haste, and appreciate them all the more because
of the effort which it must be for you to keep your
stream of correspondence/___ ____ all your other
commitments. I am glad - and so is Saxl– that you
like the work; I am sure you will create a reputa-
tion at McGill which it will be very hard for your
successors to live down. Yet, I cannot help hoping
that the need to find a successor for you may arise
very soon! You have no doubt received our cable in
reply to the two questions posed in your official letters.
They were comparatively easy to deal with, and as our
answer was not sent before we had had an opportunity
of counsulting the chairman of our Committee you can
see that the University authorities are really bent on
allowing us as much freedom to follow our own minds
as they can. They have also gone to some lengths to make
te salary attractive (according to their lights and the
state of British finance) – but of course it is trifling
compared with the sums which you mention. They seem
hard-larned, though, with teaching obligations at
two Universities! What you write about old and new
loyaltien touches me Too closely for me, to be able to comment
upon it - so there is only the third aspect of your
present conflict that needs an answer from me. The
Wording of your title as reader is a thing once
mentioned and then forgotten and buried in the aca-
demic registrar's files. It would not ___ you as
to the courses which you would give, and the limi-
tation to the "Classical Tradition" will be only stimulated
to avoid any objectives raised against the establish-
ment of another reandership on grounds of "overlapping".
In practice nobody will bother about what you
are doing (faced at any rate must be near ____
age) and it would only depend on the teaching pro-
gramme of the Warburg Institute which it would ___
___ be your own job - in consultation with Saxl - To
determine, whether systematic philosophy would
find a place in it or not with the university. think I am entitled to
say that our experience has been so far quite free
from any attempt at binding anyone to anything. As
far as the intiative has started from other Colleges
(as in the case of the Renaissance course in the history
school now given by Saxl) they will of course chose a
subject within our terms of reference and in ____
to act as an intescollegiale link; but nobody
would have objected if Saxl had wished to give a
course or lectures on Rembrandt in addition.
UNIVERSITY OF LONDON
THE WARBURG INSTITUTE
IMPERIAL INSTITUTE BUILDINGS
SOUTH KENSINGTON
LONDON S. W. 7
TELEPHONE: KENSINGTON 9077
Of course you commit yourself to the Classical Tradit-
ion by the mere fact if joining this Institute – but
then, is not your proficiency and your interest in it
the reason for why you were asked, and are contemplay-
ing to join it? And as it has been made abundantly
clear, that the Hist. of the Class. Trad. is not a pro¬
gramme to be filled – still less a subject to be ex-
______ – but a method and a way of approach,
it ______ with you to demonstrate how any given part
of systematic philosophy fits into it - let alone all
the fields which need to be chared up in the interest
of the " Warburg method" proper, like semantics etc.
but I do not thimk you were having those attempt in mind
when you wrote to me. I can only imagine any binding yet.
down to the Terms of your Readership if someone want-
ed to be very nasty – and I do not think we need to
take that eventually into arcount because et is ____-
___ in any appointment and cannot therefore be made
an eycuse for accepting or rejecting a job. It may even
be that you will be asked by other institutions to lecture
on Systematic philosophy just as for instance _____-
___ lectures at the court. Institute on the purely art
historical aspects of his subject, although his title
is Reader in the Class. Tradition in The Hist. of Art, or
as ____ is ____ by the Just. of Hist. Revarch to
give a course of the illumination to this psychology
students.
your readership is to have the added qualification
"with special Responsibilities- a chance which kind
expression in the increase of the salary, by something
like 200 € above the normal Readers salary. This,
in addition to the post of Director of Studies at the
W. T., raises yours post anyhow above the usual ?
and obligations of a Readership.
As regards your proposal to return to london for
? months during your second year of officie at Mel???
it would be excellent, in last ??? could be better, provided you would definitely decide to take ours
for good in August 1948. think on that assumption
our Committee would even be prepared to wait for
you without your ? here until the session
1948/49. But 7 am afraid you the would want a decision in the course of Thissames term. When your
label was read at The last meetings the Temper of the
committee was obviously in favour of making all
allowances provided the answer would be "yes" until
monday. If They could count on That they might give
in order.
you the time you want, to leave McGill with all due
consideration for them. And provided you were quite
decided to take up the post here in Auguet 1948 you
might prefer to spend the inter? times either
entirely at Mechill or divide it between Canada and
U. S. A. But for us your offer would be admirable.
University of London
The Warburg Institute
Imperial Institute Buildings
South Kensington
London S. W.7
Telephone Kensington 9077
Gax would welcome your help enourmously, ?
might he made plans laid, and currieula prepared
To your liking in anticipation of better Things to follow.
There is one more thing which I ? must
add- at the risks of appearing to attempt a bit of
Hackmail. Saxt ist- as Warburg used to say - allright
from the collar upward and his health is infinitely
better then it was last year. He will carry gladly all
te burdens imposed of him, and there is no chances
of him breaking down under them. But some mystery
??? has gone out of his resilience. He is
tired much more easily than he ued to be, and with
tiredness a kind of irritation comes over him
at times which takes his energy, his emotions and
his will to achieve. In the long run this must affect
his work. Up till now he always pulls himself together
But what I feel ( or rather know) is that This would
disappear the moment he would know that, some
date you woud come to help him. He would feel The
Institute was safe, in good strong hands; There
would be someone to assist consolidation in, and
he would not be alone to do everything single and
? for an indefinite period of time. This should not
decide ? – no doubt he would be very ? in the
me for mentioning him at all – but if the balance
is anyhow slightly in ? of your acceptance
the post here it might make it a little easier for
you to do it gladly, knowing that a little bit of
human relationship would be added to the seale
in which the objective pros are being weighed.
The first part of Melancolia Trans-
lated is with Lo?? - for revision of the Translation
of the Greek texts. When she returns it work will go
on. And I am also now writing to Miss Tsemay (?)
asking her whether there is a chance now of her
coming to work in London.
I love to have to go to a lecture
and do just want this letter to be delayed any
longer.
All good wishes and kindest
regards from yours
G. ß.
